title: George Biondo
text:
George Michael Biondo (born September 3, 1945 in <a href="Brooklyn">Brooklyn</a>, <a href="New%20York%20City">New York</a>) was the <a href="bass%20guitar">bass guitar</a>ist of the <a href="Canadian">Canadian</a> <a href="rock%20band">rock band</a> <a href="Steppenwolf%20%28band%29">Steppenwolf</a>, from April 1970 to October 1976. Though born in <a href="New%20York%20City">New York</a>, he has been based in <a href="Southern%20California">Southern California</a> throughout his ongoing career as a <a href="session%20musician">session musician</a> and <a href="songwriter">songwriter</a>.
Early career.
Biondo played <a href="bass%20guitar">bass</a> in a <a href="Los%20Angeles%2C%20California">Los Angeles</a> area band called Storybook People during which time they released a <a href="single%20%28music%29">single</a> on <a href="Dunhill%20Records">Dunhill Records</a>, which received limited <a href="airplay%20%28radio%29">airplay</a> in Los Angeles. In 1968, Biondo replaced <a href="Nick%20St.%20Nicholas">Nick St. Nicholas</a> in another Los Angeles area band called T.I.M.E., when St. Nicholas departed for Steppenwolf. After T.I.M.E. guitarist Larry Byrom also left to join Steppenwolf, T.I.M.E. briefly attempted to carry on with Biondo as lead <a href="singing">singer</a>, but never released any further <a href="sound%20recording%20and%20reproduction">recordings</a>.
Steppenwolf.
In early 1970, Biondo replaced St. Nicholas a second time when he joined Steppenwolf for the recording of "<a href="Steppenwolf%207">Steppenwolf 7</a>", contributing lead vocals on "Fat Jack" and co-lead vocals on "Foggy Mental Breakdown" and the chart-hit, "Who Needs Ya'". In 1971, the band released their last new album for Dunhill, "<a href="For%20Ladies%20Only">For Ladies Only</a>" for which Biondo wrote "Sparkle Eyes" with <a href="John%20Kay%20%28musician%29">John Kay</a> and "In Hopes of a Garden". He sang lead on the latter, as well as "Jaded Strumpet". When Steppenwolf went on hiatus in 1972, Biondo became a founding member of the <a href="John%20Kay%20%28musician%29">John Kay Band</a>, appearing on both of Kay's solo albums on Dunhill Records. When Steppenwolf reconvened in the mid-1970s, Biondo was brought back for the album "<a href="Slow%20Flux">Slow Flux</a>". Then writing "Two for the Love of One" for the "<a href="Hour%20of%20the%20Wolf%20%28album%29">Hour of the Wolf</a>" album. Biondo later wrote "Sleep" and co-wrote the instrumental "Lip Service" with <a href="Bobby%20Cochran">Bobby Cochran</a> and <a href="Wayne%20Cook">Wayne Cook</a> for the "<a href="Skullduggery%20%28album%29">Skullduggery</a>" album in 1976. In 1981, Biondo added backing vocals to "<a href="Wolftracks">Wolftracks</a>", the first <a href="recording%20studio">studio</a> album by John Kay and his new band, now under the moniker "John Kay & Steppenwolf".
After Steppenwolf.
In 1980, Biondo reunited with Steppenwolf cofounder <a href="Jerry%20Edmonton">Jerry Edmonton</a> in a band called Steel Rose. A Steel Rose single penned by Biondo, "Good That You're Gone", was released on Dore Records, and featured Biondo on lead vocals. When Steel Rose disbanded in 1984, Biondo returned to writing and freelance club and session work.
